questionContent.body: Which of the following is an application of NN (Neural Network)?
What is back propagation?

questionOptions.body: It is another name given to the curvy function in the perceptron
It is the transmission of error back through the network to adjust the inputs
It is the transmission of error back through the network to allow weights to be adjusted so that the network can learn

questionContent.body: What is error in perceptron model of neuron?

questionOptions.body: can be both due to difference in target output or environmental condition

questionContent.body: When both inputs are 1, what will be the output of the pitts model nand gate ?

An artificial neuron receives n inputs x1, x2, x3............xn with weights w1, w2, ..........wn attached to the input links. The weighted sum_________________ is computed to be passed on to a non-linear filter Φ called activation function to release the output.
A perceptron adds up all the weighted inputs it receives, and if it exceeds a certain value, it outputs a 1, otherwise it just outputs a 0

questionOptions.body: Sometimes – it can also output intermediate values as well

questionContent.body: What is perceptron?

questionOptions.body: a single layer feed-forward neural network with pre-processing
a double layer auto-associative neural network
a neural network that contains feedback

questionContent.body: What is the main functionality of Keras in the context of machine learning?

Which Python library is commonly used for machine learning tasks and includes functions for data preprocessing, model building, and evaluation?

questionOptions.body: Weight between input and hidden layer
Weight between hidden and output layer
Biases of all hidden layer neurons

questionContent.body: Suppose we have a neural network with ReLU activation function. Let’s say, we replace ReLu activations by linear activations. questionContent.body: Which of the following hyperparameters controls the learning rate in boosting algorithms?
Why is boosting considered more prone to overfitting than bagging?

questionOptions.body: Because it trains weak models independently
Because it sequentially learns from the mistakes of previous models, fitting the noise
Because it only uses random subsets of data

questionContent.body: In a boosting ensemble, how are the final predictions made?

questionOptions.body: By taking the average of all weak learners
By majority voting of the weak models
By weighting each model’s prediction based on its accuracy
By using the first model’s prediction as final output

questionContent.body: What type of models does boosting typically use as weak learners?
In Gradient Boosting, what is the role of the loss function?

questionOptions.body: It determines the splitting criterion in decision trees
It guides the boosting algorithm to minimize prediction errors
It helps in selecting the best hyperparameters

questionContent.body: A dataset has a highly imbalanced class distribution. Which boosting technique is most suitable?
Which of the following boosting algorithms is based on gradient optimization?
How does AdaBoost assign weights to misclassified samples?

questionOptions.body: It increases the weights of correctly classified samples
It decreases the weights of misclassified samples
It increases the weights of misclassified samples to focus on them in the next iteration
It assigns equal weights to all samples

questionContent.body: Why does boosting improve the overall predictive performance of a model?

questionOptions.body: By reducing variance and ignoring bias
By combining weak learners to correct the mistakes of previous models
By training deep networks with high capacity
By using only a single decision tree for learning

questionContent.body: What is the main objective of boosting in machine learning?

questionOptions.body: To reduce bias by training multiple weak models sequentially
To increase overfitting by training deep neural networks
To replace decision trees with neural networks
To train all weak models independently

questionContent.body: How does Bagging improve model generalization?

questionOptions.body: By reducing overfitting through averaging multiple models
By removing weak models from the ensemble

questionContent.body: In which scenario would Bagging NOT be an ideal choice?

questionOptions.body: When the model suffers from high variance

questionContent.body: Which of the following hyperparameters can be adjusted in a Bagging Classifier in sklearn?
If you apply Bagging to Logistic Regression, what will be the expected outcome?

questionOptions.body: It will not provide significant benefits
It will make the model slower but more accurate

questionContent.body: Which ensemble method is a direct application of Bagging?
How does Bagging impact the interpretability of a model?

questionOptions.body: It improves interpretability by using multiple models
It reduces interpretability due to ensemble complexity
It has no impact on interpretability

questionContent.body: Bagging is particularly useful when applied to:
In a Bagging ensemble of Decision Trees, what happens if we do NOT use bootstrap sampling?

questionOptions.body: The model will have lower bias

questionContent.body: Which of the following statements is TRUE about Bagging and Boosting?

questionOptions.body: Bagging reduces variance, whereas Boosting reduces bias
Bagging reduces bias, whereas Boosting reduces variance
Both Bagging and Boosting increase variance
Bagging and Boosting are the same technique

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of Bagging?

questionOptions.body: It creates multiple subsets of data
It builds models sequentially like Boosting
It combines predictions using averaging or voting

questionContent.body: Suppose you use Bagging with Decision Trees on a dataset with high variance. What would you expect?

questionOptions.body: The overall variance of the model will reduce
The model will memorize the training set
The decision trees will all be identicall

questionContent.body: In Bagging, what is the role of aggregation in final prediction?

questionOptions.body: It selects the most complex model
It selects the model with the highest accuracy
It averages the outputs for regression and takes majority votes for classification

questionContent.body: What type of models benefit the most from Bagging?
Which of the following is an advantage of Bagging?

questionOptions.body: It always increases accuracy, regardless of the base model
It reduces overfitting in high-variance models
It works only with linear models
It removes bias completely from the model

questionContent.body: What happens when we increase the number of base models in a Bagging ensemble?

questionOptions.body: The bias of the model increases
The variance of the model increases
The variance of the model decreases

questionContent.body: Consider a scenario where a single Decision Tree model overfits the training data. How can Bagging help in this situation?

questionOptions.body: By reducing bias in the decision tree
By increasing model complexity to fit training data better
By averaging multiple decision trees to reduce variance
By using a single, larger decision tree

questionContent.body: Which of the following algorithms is commonly used with Bagging?
How does Bootstrap Sampling work in Bagging?

questionOptions.body: It selects only the best samples from the dataset
It generates multiple subsets of data with replacement
It uses all available training data without modification
It selects a completely different dataset for each model

questionContent.body: Why does Bagging improve model performance?

questionOptions.body: By training models on different datasets and averaging predictions
By selecting the best model from a set of trained models
By reducing the number of trees in the ensemble

questionContent.body: What is the primary purpose of Bagging in ensemble learning?

questionOptions.body: To reduce variance and improve stability
To make the model more complex

questionContent.body: What is one advantage of using SVD in dimensionality reduction?

questionOptions.body: It retains the most important information while reducing noise
It eliminates the need for feature scaling
It works only with categorical data
It increases data complexity for better accuracy

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SVD helps extract the most significant features from data while filtering out noise, making it useful for compression and feature selection.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a common application of SVD in machine learning?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SVD is widely used in dimensionality reduction (e.g., Latent Semantic Analysis) and collaborative filtering in recommendation systems.

questionContent.body: In Singular Value Decomposition (SVD), which three matrices represent the decomposed form of a given matrix A?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SVD decomposes a matrix A into U(left singular vectors), Σ (singular values), and VT (right singular vectors).

questionContent.body: What is the primary purpose of Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) in machine learning?

questionOptions.body: To decompose a matrix into three lower-dimensional matrices for efficient computation
To normalize feature values in a dataset
To encode categorical variables into numerical format
To increase the number of features in a dataset

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SVD factorizes a matrix into three components (U, Σ, V^T), helping in dimensionality reduction and noise reduction.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a common limitation of PCA?

questionOptions.body: It only works with categorical data
It is sensitive to the scale of features
It requires labeled data for training

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: PCA is affected by feature scaling; applying standardization (Z-score normalization) before PCA helps achieve better results.

questionContent.body: Which mathematical technique is used in PCA to compute principal components?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: PCA uses SVD or Eigenvalue decomposition to transform data into a new coordinate system based on principal components.

questionContent.body: What does PCA prioritize when selecting principal components?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: PCA selects components that capture the most variance in the dataset, as higher variance typically holds more information.

questionContent.body: What is the primary purpose of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) in machine learning?

questionOptions.body: To reduce the number of features while retaining most of the data’s variance
To normalize feature values to a specific range
To encode categorical variables into numerical form
To improve model accuracy by adding more features

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: PCA reduces dimensionality by transforming correlated features into a smaller set of uncorrelated principal components.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a common technique used for feature extraction in image processing?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: PCA extracts important features by reducing data dimensionality while retaining significant variance in the dataset.

questionContent.body: What is the main objective of feature extraction in machine learning?

questionOptions.body: To create new informative features from raw data
To remove all irrelevant features from a dataset
To normalize data for better performance
To replace missing values with estimated values

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Feature extraction transforms raw data into meaningful representations that improve model performance and efficiency.

questionContent.body: What does Principal Component Analysis (PC[KEY=A] do in dimensionality reduction?

questionOptions.body: It normalizes feature values to a standard range
It transforms correlated features into a set of uncorrelated principal components
It replaces missing values in a dataset
It encodes categorical variables into numerical form

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: PCA reduces dimensionality by projecting data onto new axes, capturing the most variance while minimizing information loss.

questionContent.body: What is the main goal of dimensionality reduction in machine learning?

questionOptions.body: To increase the number of features in a dataset
To remove irrelevant or redundant features while preserving important information
To convert numerical data into categorical data
To improve overfitting by adding more complexity

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Dimensionality reduction helps simplify models, reduce computation time, and improve generalization by eliminating less important features.

questionContent.body: What is a common drawback of One-Hot Encoding?

questionOptions.body: It only works for numerical data

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One-Hot Encoding creates separate binary columns for each category, which can lead to high-dimensional data, especially for features with many unique values.

questionContent.body: Why is One-Hot Encoding used in machine learning?

questionOptions.body: To convert categorical variables into binary vectors

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One-Hot Encoding transforms categorical data into a format that machine learning models can understand by creating binary columns for each category.

questionContent.body: Which imputation method predicts missing values based on other features in the dataset?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: KNN imputation estimates missing values by considering the most similar data points in the dataset.

questionContent.body: Which imputation technique replaces missing values with the average or middle value of a feature?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Mean or median imputation fills missing values with the average or middle value of the feature to maintain data consistency.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT a common approach to handling outliers?

questionOptions.body: Removing them if they distort the analysis
Replacing them with the mean or median
Using transformation techniques like log scaling

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Ignoring outliers without analysis can negatively impact model performance; handling them depends on the dataset and problem context.

questionContent.body: Which statistical method is commonly used to detect outliers in a dataset?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Z-Score helps detect outliers by measuring how many standard deviations a data point is away from the mean.

questionContent.body: Which method is commonly used to detect outliers in a dataset?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Z-Score measures how far a data point is from the mean in terms of standard deviations, helping identify outliers.

questionContent.body: Which technique is commonly used to convert categorical data into numerical format?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One-Hot Encoding transforms categorical variables into binary vectors, making them suitable for machine learning models.

questionOptions.body: When finding hidden patterns in data

The number of clusters must be predefined

questionContent.body: You are using Naïve Bayes for text classification. You observe that the classifier is overly sensitive to rare words. What technique can mitigate this issue?

questionOptions.body: Applying TF-IDF weighting instead of raw frequency
Using a Decision Tree instead of Naïve Bayes

questionContent.body: A Decision Tree model is trained on customer purchase data. It predicts that all customers will buy a product regardless of their features. What is likely wrong?

questionOptions.body: The model has too many leaves
The training data has class imbalance
The decision tree has been pruned too much

questionContent.body: Your SVM classifier is training very slowly on a dataset with millions of features. What technique can improve efficiency?

questionOptions.body: Feature selection or dimensionality reduction (e.g., PCA)

questionContent.body: A Decision Tree classifier has many levels and performs poorly on new data. What can be done to improve its generalization?

questionOptions.body: Increase the depth of the tree
Reduce the number of training samples
Change to a linear regression model

questionContent.body: You are training an SVM on a dataset where some classes have overlapping distributions. Which of the following strategies can help improve performance?

questionOptions.body: Reducing the number of support vectors

questionContent.body: You have an imbalanced dataset where 95% of the instances belong to one class. Which classifier is most likely to perform poorly without modifications?
In an SVM model, the dataset is not linearly separable, and you do not achieve good classification accuracy. What should you try next?

questionOptions.body: Use a non-linear kernel such as RBF

questionContent.body: A spam email classifier is trained using Naïve Bayes. One of the words in the test email does not appear in the training data. How does Naïve Bayes handle this?

questionOptions.body: It assigns zero probability to the class
It ignores the word and proceeds with classification
It uses Laplace (or additive) smoothing to handle unseen words
It refuses to classify the email

questionContent.body: You are building a Decision Tree model, and you observe that it performs well on training data but poorly on test data. What is the likely reason?
In which case is the Naïve Bayes classifier most effective?

questionOptions.body: When there are many missing values
When the dataset is small and features are independent
When deep learning models are used

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of Decision Trees?

questionOptions.body: Handles both categorical and numerical data
Always results in the best model

questionContent.body: What happens when a large value of C is used in an SVM classifier?

questionOptions.body: The model tries to perfectly classify the training data

questionContent.body: Which kernel is commonly used in SVM when the data is not linearly separable?
What is the primary objective of a Support Vector Machine (SVM)?

questionOptions.body: To minimize variance in the dataset
To find a hyperplane that best separates different classes
To cluster data points into groups

questionContent.body: What is the main advantage of Naïve Bayes classifiers?

questionOptions.body: They require large amounts of training data
They work well even with small datasets

questionContent.body: Which assumption is fundamental to the Naïve Bayes classifier?

questionOptions.body: Features are dependent on each other
Features are independent given the class
All data must be normally distributed

questionContent.body: Naïve Bayes is based on which theorem?
Which of the following best describes a Decision Tree?

questionOptions.body: A hierarchical structure used for classification and regression
